title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0001
text: What is the primary purpose of the Saga pattern in microservices?

options.text: To manage distributed transactions across multiple services

explanation: The Saga pattern coordinates distributed transactions across multiple services using a sequence of local transactions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0002
text: Which of the following best describes a Saga?

options.text: A sequence of local transactions coordinated to maintain data consistency
A single global transaction across all services

explanation: A Saga is a sequence of local transactions where each step updates data within a service and triggers the next step.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0003
text: Which of the following is a key benefit of the Saga pattern?

options.text: Ensures eventual consistency without distributed transactions
Provides strong consistency across all services
Eliminates the need for compensation logic

explanation: The Saga pattern ensures eventual consistency across services without using distributed transactions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0004
text: What is a compensating transaction in a Saga?

options.text: A transaction that undoes the effects of a previous step in case of failure
A transaction that retries failed operations
A transaction that commits all changes
A transaction that logs audit data

explanation: A compensating transaction reverses the effects of a previous local transaction when a failure occurs.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0005
text: Which of the following are the two main types of Saga implementations?
explanation: The two main Saga implementation styles are Choreography (event-driven) and Orchestration (centralized coordinator).

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0006
text: In a choreography-based Saga, how do services communicate?

options.text: Through events published and subscribed by each service

explanation: In choreography-based Sagas, services communicate by publishing and subscribing to domain events.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0007
text: In an orchestration-based Saga, what component coordinates the workflow?
explanation: In orchestration-based Sagas, a Saga orchestrator coordinates the sequence of local transactions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0008
text: Which of the following is a key advantage of choreography-based Sagas?
explanation: Choreography-based Sagas are decentralized and do not require a central coordinator.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0009
text: Which of the following is a disadvantage of choreography-based Sagas?

options.text: Complex event coordination and potential cyclic dependencies

explanation: Choreography-based Sagas can become complex due to event chains and cyclic dependencies.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0010
text: Which of the following is a key advantage of orchestration-based Sagas?

options.text: Centralized control and visibility of the workflow

explanation: Orchestration-based Sagas provide centralized control and visibility through a Saga orchestrator.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0011
text: Which of the following is a disadvantage of orchestration-based Sagas?

options.text: Introduces a single point of failure

explanation: The orchestrator can become a single point of failure in orchestration-based Sagas.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0012
text: What type of consistency does the Saga pattern provide?
explanation: The Saga pattern provides eventual consistency across distributed services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0013
text: Which of the following is a common use case for the Saga pattern?
explanation: The Saga pattern is commonly used for order processing workflows involving multiple services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0014
text: Which of the following is a key challenge in implementing Sagas?

options.text: Designing compensation logic for failed transactions

explanation: Designing compensation logic for failed transactions is one of the main challenges in implementing Sagas.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0015
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using Sagas for reliability?

options.text: Allows recovery from partial failures through compensation

explanation: Sagas improve reliability by allowing recovery from partial failures through compensating transactions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0016
text: Which of the following is a common communication mechanism used in Sagas?
explanation: Sagas typically use asynchronous messaging to coordinate transactions across services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0017
text: Which of the following is a key difference between Sagas and two-phase commit (2PC)?

options.text: Sagas use compensation instead of locks for rollback
Sagas require a global transaction manager
Sagas block all participants until commit

explanation: Unlike 2PC, Sagas use compensating transactions instead of locks to handle rollbacks.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0018
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for scalability?
explanation: Sagas improve scalability by avoiding distributed locks and blocking operations.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0019
text: Which of the following is a common tool used to implement Sagas?
explanation: Axon Framework provides support for implementing Sagas in event-driven microservices.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0020
text: Which of the following best summarizes the Saga pattern?

options.text: A sequence of local transactions coordinated to maintain eventual consistency across services
A single global transaction across all services

explanation: The Saga pattern coordinates local transactions across services to maintain eventual consistency.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0021
text: Which of the following is a key responsibility of the Saga orchestrator?

options.text: Coordinating the execution and compensation of local transactions

explanation: The Saga orchestrator coordinates the execution and compensation of local transactions across services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0022
text: Which of the following is a common challenge in Saga orchestration?
explanation: Handling partial failures and retries is a key challenge in Saga orchestration.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0023
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for fault tolerance?
explanation: Sagas improve fault tolerance by allowing recovery through compensating transactions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0024
text: Which of the following is a disadvantage of Sagas?
explanation: Sagas require complex compensation logic to handle failures and maintain consistency.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0025
text: Which of the following is a common communication pattern used in Sagas?
explanation: Sagas typically use event-driven messaging to coordinate distributed transactions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0026
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for scalability?
explanation: Sagas improve scalability by avoiding distributed locks and blocking operations.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0027
text: Which of the following is a common tool for implementing Saga orchestration?
explanation: Camunda is a popular workflow engine used to implement Saga orchestration.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0028
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for reliability?

options.text: Ensures eventual consistency even after partial failures

explanation: Sagas ensure eventual consistency even after partial failures through compensation.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0029
text: Which of the following is a key difference between choreography and orchestration?

options.text: Choreography is decentralized, orchestration is centralized
Choreography uses a coordinator, orchestration does not
Choreography is synchronous, orchestration is asynchronous

explanation: Choreography is decentralized and event-driven, while orchestration uses a central coordinator.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0030
text: Which of the following is a common use case for Sagas?
explanation: Sagas are commonly used in e-commerce order management to coordinate multiple services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0031
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for decoupling?

options.text: Services communicate through events rather than direct calls

explanation: Sagas promote decoupling by using event-driven communication between services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0032
text: Which of the following is a disadvantage of Sagas for debugging?

options.text: Difficult to trace events across multiple services

explanation: Tracing events across multiple services in a Saga can be difficult, complicating debugging.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0033
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for resilience?

options.text: Can recover from partial failures using compensation

explanation: Sagas improve resilience by allowing recovery from partial failures using compensating transactions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0034
text: Which of the following is a common challenge in Saga choreography?
explanation: Managing complex event chains is a challenge in choreography-based Sagas.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0035
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for observability?

options.text: Provides visibility into distributed transaction flows

explanation: Sagas provide visibility into distributed transaction flows, improving observability.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0036
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for maintainability?

options.text: Encapsulates transaction logic within each service
Centralizes all logic in one service

explanation: Sagas encapsulate transaction logic within each service, improving maintainability.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0037
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for automation?
explanation: Sagas automate distributed transaction coordination across services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0038
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for fault recovery?

options.text: Allows replaying failed transactions through compensation

explanation: Sagas allow replaying failed transactions through compensation for fault recovery.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0039
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for integration?
explanation: Sagas enable integration through event-driven workflows across services.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0040
text: Which of the following best summarizes the Saga pattern?

options.text: A distributed transaction pattern that ensures eventual consistency through local transactions and compensation

explanation: The Saga pattern ensures eventual consistency through local transactions and compensating actions.

title: MicroservicesServiceCollaborationSaga - Q0041
text: Which of the following is a benefit of Sagas for decoupling?
explanation: Sagas promote decoupling by using asynchronous event-based communication.
